comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I thought just for the craic I might say up a bit down a bit but in fact this is exactly right on the sweet spot!  There are a couple of small buildings between the Garda Station and Glengarriff Parade.  At the time it was of course the Dublin Metropolitan Police who occupied that building and the officers "lived in" there.  The kitchens were in the basement below and the dormitories were in the upper stories.

comment.author: 45224155@N06
comment._content: I read about Sinn Fein in Ulysses by James Joyce.

comment.author: 45785863@N06
comment._content: 19/04/1920 (Irish independent page 3) I have seen several other images in books and newspapers that show these armoured cars and large tanks mixed in with Hugh crowds during the hunger strike in Mountjoy. The car is almost identical to the Peerless but this is an Austin armoured car and the “”white-red-white”” badge/flag on the side is the markings of the British 17th tank battalion, which saw service in the great war. The 17th arrived in Ireland in January 1919. The twin turrets of these cars which were originally designed in 1914 were still been used by the Irish army during World War Two on Irish built Ford armoured cars. It's great to get some dates and locations with these excellent photos. THANKS TO ALL... peerlessarmouredcar.blogspot.com/2012/01/austin-peerless-...

comment.author: 22575440@N07
comment._content: thanks Niall for providing the link for what it looks like today. I would say the whole bldg and area looks like they have cleaned it up nicely!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/vintary] Thanks again for your great information. I checked in the Irish Independent but actually found it on page 3 of Tuesday, 13 April 1920. The headline was The Mountjoy Crisis and the caption simply says An armoured car at Mountjoy Prison yesterday with the inscription, "Up, Sinn Fein!" Ding Ding Ding! That's our NLI Flickr Bell ringing because another photo has gotten its date... :)

comment.author: 87900113@N02
comment._content:
I had a part-time job as a messenger boy in the mid-fifties for the local grocers, Conroys. The single Guards and Warders had accounts there and I delivered their orders into Mounjoy Garda Station and also inside Mountjoy Prison. The whole frontage area of the prison has changed considerably. The Station is virtually the same architecturally but the entrance road has been widened and the wall to the left of the standing soldier has been demolished. The kitchens were downstairs as noted already and the single guards slept upstairs in the dormitory. There was also a handball alley at the back of the station where we often played and were chased away by Guards who had been on night duty trying to get some sleep!

The Station provided armed guards for Mountjoy Prison entrance during the IRA Fifties Campaign.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/87900113@N02] Lovely information, thank you! Can just imagine sleep-deprived Guards being driven mad by the thud of the ball...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
